												New Retro Arcade: Neon is my new Life.Ok - HUGE caveat: 1. New Retro Arcade: Neon does NOT come with arcade machines loaded with games to play. You must modify them yourself with emulators and roms which must be acquired on your own.2. This game is VERY buggy right now, it almost should have been an early access game.3. This game is very much intended to be modified to suit your needs, but requires you to have some decent problem solving and research skills to figure out how to work all of the features to make it shine. It is not for the feint of heart .. or 'mind' in this case.Despite those points I am still recommending this title.NRA-N is the BEST emulation lobby you will ever encounter. The immersion factor is THROUGH THE ROOF on this one, you get to walk around an 80's-90's style arcade environment which includes many interactable features and mini-games such as the ticket-style games you would typically find in an arcade like: ski-ball, basketball hoop shooting, darts, air hockey.Then, with the NRA-N configuration tool you can add:Each arcade can emulate a game of your choosing, so that when you walk up to it and interact it loads the game and it plays on the screen IN the environment! You dont even leave NRA-N .. if you want to stop playing that arcade machine .. just turn around and walk away to another .. start that one up and play. The feeling you get when doing this will flash you right back to the 90's when you slammed your fist down after losing at a game and the continue screen appears and starts to count down.There are game cartridges littered throughout the environment, using the config tool you can make these  games emulate any SNES/Genesis/NES or other console game, instead of just interacting with it, you have to physically pick it up and put it into the game console and it will start playing on a CRT screen. Just think, in 2016, you can play Super Metroid on a CRT screen on your top tier PC in VR.There are cassette tapes littered all over the place, you can use the config tool to load these up with any MP3 you want and then plug them into a cassette player to play whatever song you want to set the mood.There are VHS tapes you can set to movie files so you can watch Aliens .. or Terminator 2 on a CRT TV! - note however this feature is currently buggy for some people. I have gotten it to work but without sound, still trying to mess with it .. but the tech is there! .. it should work eventually!You can modify posters, you can modify the graphics of the arcade machines .. the graphics of the cartridges.Or you can just chill and throw darts at a wall.NRA-N is my new life. It's still janky .. its still being worked on despite being released .. but I dont CARE! .. ITS AWESOME! and I still recommend it in spite of its flaws.

The side panel graphics, the marquees, and the button and stick arrangements?  You'll have to configure those for your games, too.  Remember that you'll have to do this for each game in your arcade.  They provide an "arcade builder" tool which makes this less difficult than it would be if you had to custom-write your own xml, but4) SOME DOCUMENTATION WOULD BE NICE.   As of 8/24/2016, the documentation that I can find is this: 


Official Arcade Builder Guide 
A Guide for NewRetroArcade: Neon
By: Vermillion

			This guide instructs users on how to add their ROMs and custom artwork to New Retro Arcade: NEON

First the good - It perfectly recreates the arcade experience, which is what DC was going for, so that's great. Now the bad - For those of us, like myself, which have been following this from the very beginning, it has been nearly all about emulation. Not nearly enough to fit most of the games you truly loved to play. The arcade needs the ability to knock down walls, and remove the pieces you don't want, and replace them with more (and varied) cabinet styles. Once that piece is in place, at least for me, it will be what I am looking for. Until then, a great experience, but missing that one special piece that could have made our emulation dreams come true.

												This is truly an incredible experience.  I can't help but smile when entering this virtual space. Yes, there are a few quirks here and there regarding a few emulations (I can't seem the get the "game boys" to work, and the snes plays great, but it does sound off), but I can start up the 1989 Batman, then decide to walk in the other room to play some Super Mario World, or air hockey while Army of Darkness plays next to it. Then, when I'm bored with that, walk back into the screening room to finish Batman, which I left running. And the atmosphere, and stock games alone are worth the price.I understand this as a total passion project for the developers, and I have no doubt they'll tie up the few loose ends in no time. However, those who're expecting to play two player roms online should probably forget about that. The developers gave us bowling, air hockey, hoop shot, whack-a-mole, and skeeball to play with friends. I haven't tried 2-player yet, so I don't know if others can see your emulations running, but all I hope for is to have friends cheer/tease me while they watch me play Ms Pacman.I would love the tapes to be able to hold entire albums instead of just one song; and I'd love some cheesy, cliche bowling alley animatics when someone gets a strike, or spare, or gutterball, etc.Edit:"Game boys" are working perfectly now! This game has an incredibly responsive development team! One thing to note further for potential buyers though, I've only been able to get the cabinet arcade games to play 80s arcade games, or prior (basically Golden Axe (1989) is the newest game I've been able to run through MAME on them). Don't expect to play Marvel vs Capcom just yet. However, you can run the SNES emulator on the cabinets, so I can still play TMNT: Turtles in Time, and NBA Jam, but it just doesn't have the same feel. By that, I mean it always saves, and picks up right where I left off. It doesn't do that with the MAME games. That's an incredible feature for typical SNES games, but I'd like the option to reset so it feels like I'm walking in on a new day of arcade action when I re-enter the game.Guys, despite my criticisms, I've never been happier buying a game before. This game deserves more love, and attention.

If you however have a decent collection of MAME roms, SNES or Gameboy roms then oh my this game will really bring those roms to life by giving you a virtual playground where to mess around with them. Sega Megadrive does not work at this time so check what it supports if you have exotic emulation tastes. So let's do a short Pro's and Con's list. Pro's+ Being there feeling can't get any closer. Just use the lovely 3rd party software ArcadeManager to make attract videos for your cabinets and presto. The racket, the chatter and general noise is just like the real deal was in the past. + Did i mention the immersion? It really is the number #1 here. Good (customizable) soundtracks too. + Awesome _software_ for the person who wants to take their arcade experience to the next level. And the really important Con's- No ROMs included. If you don't at this point understand what i mean by this then you REALLY need to skip this. - Limited multiplay. Others can't play your ROMs so multiplayer is just messing around playing the non ROM related games that can be found at this time.  There is no video streaming or anything like that. - Some people do seem to be confused what this program actually is. I say it straight that this is a _software_ , a glorious front-end for your ROM's.  - _This is not a game where you get to play real, licensed old games in a awesome virtual arcade_+- Some people might think the common area games are enough to warrant a buy. I disagree. Bowling, darts, some ball throwing games plus other misc activities where you can mess around with your environment. As fun as they are they are not good enough to warrant a buy alone and this purchase is not exactly cheap so that's a No. Don't buy this game just for the vanilla experience. This one requires you to modify it to your tastes. So with further ado i fully recommend this to people who are fans of old arcades and are in some way active in the scene. The rest be advised of the important con's i listed above.

I'll do my best to keep it fair but my excitement will most likely be taking over as I write this review.I was born in 1980 and NRA:N is just hitting all the major marks for me.I played the game with my daughter for a while (She's 3 years old so the nostalgic aspect is a bit lost on her) but we had a lot of fun. The moment she saw the title screen she was all like "pretty colors" and "It's so beautiful daddy", and she's right. Digital Cybercherries are so on-point when it comes to design aesthetics its awe-inspiring.  Incredibly well designed visuals which truly hit the mark regarding the "retro" look and feel. As an 80's kid myself, I love being able to go back to that time for a brief moment and capsulate that experience.Pros:- Highly immersive 80's and 90's experience.- Incredible high quality assets and attention to detail.- Amazing overall design Aesthetics that hit the mark in every aspect for me.- Actual physics based games that work splendidly, very fun to play with friends.- Rom integration is solid and so easy to set up.- The 80's robot... Me and my daughter love that thing to death.Cons:- Some controls on some of the physics games are a bit lacking when using a game pad (I'm using Xbox 360). But they're designed for VR controls so not much to complain about.- Wish the tapes would display the title I enter in the Arcade Builder app.- It would also be nice if some sort of preview option was available when tweaking an arcade cabinet inside the builder tool and to be able to know its location and which map it's in as well. It's a bit tedious having to head over to the guide all the time.- The screening room needs an audio option that can go louder then it's current volume level.- Not able to eat those darn delicious looking cupcakes and brownies :(It's a bit odd playing with a controller without the VR so things like bowling and playing darts aren't as fun I imagine as when using a headset. That said I LOVE the screening room. I hooked up some flicks and watched some proper 80's movies. It's a lot more fun watching it in NRA:N then the standard video player. :) While New Retro Arcade: Neon is not a game in it's own right, the amount of fun that can be had is enormous. I set up and played some TMNT on one of the arcade machines and that's one of the areas where NRA:N really shines. The scan lines and the shader effects used on the cabinet screens are amazing. truly brought me back to when I was playing them as a wee lad. The game runs like a well oiled machine and I had immense fun. I'd fully recommend New Retro Arcade: Neon to anyone who wants to either go back in time and experience it again, or for those who grew up after the 80's and 90's and want to experience a bit of what it was like back then.And for those complaining about the lack of multiplayer ROM options, that's not fair to expect. the games back then weren't designed for online multiplayer even online play within emulators are worthless and simply hardly ever work and when they do it's just too laggy.I would however, hope they can add a feature where you can watch others play. Now THAT would bring me back proper to the days I was watching older kids play games waiting for my turn. :)

Push it to the limits...Retro Arcade offers a fun 3D environment where you can setup and play your favourite arcades trough a fancy looking arcade cabinets, play an actual SNES on a old CRT TV, gameboy on an actual gameboy, Watch movies on a projector or listen to nice tunes from the internet... the possibilities are quite endless.As of now the whole concept seems quite shallow tho. Running the emulators require a different set of "LibRetro Cores" wich means new'er emulators such as Ps1, N64, Ps2... cannot be emulated at all trough the "game" world and only older emulations like NES and SNES are supported.Good: Graphics (The game looks rather nice running on a Unreal Engine) Sound Design (Lots of arcade machines playing audio at the same time generates a realistic feel) Customization (Can make your own art for the cabinets)Bad: Lack of emulation support: Due to the fact that you cant use new'er emulators kind of sets the whole game down a notch, not being able to play Ps2 games or the WiiU titles trough Cemu in the arcade is quite a drawback. If the devs could come up a way to support almost any type of emulator in the game it would make the experience much more worth it. No Fullscreen or closeups: Now the game is trying to emulate a realistic feel of an arcade and it achieves it by using filters and effects over the game screen that make the game look like your playing it on a old TV or monitor, wich makes you not want to play the games more than 10 minutes at a time. Arcade Manager is little hard to useIn all and all the retro arcade is a really fun way to experience your favourite games and if eventually we get support for most if not all the emulators out there, it could become one of the best ways to play emulators.

												The Ultimate Graphical User Interface for Emulators that will one day serve as the all time best experience for old timers like myself wanting to get nostalgic and revisit their childhood.Having owned computers/ console for over 30yrs and even using emulators for 20yrs including MAME I can only say that New Retro Arcade is the true icing on the cake that makes MAME what it should be.Having seen the demo of NRA over 1yr ago it was instantly on my top list of things to have once VR hit the mass consumer market. Since the demo a few more normal style games have been added to the arcade room layout, (Basketball and ball throwing games, ten pin bowling and Air Hockey).NRA offers 2 rooms with a few different features filled with old 80's/ 90's memorabilia and of course Arcade Cabinets for you to setup your arcade games on including the cabinet art work provided by the loving spirited community members like myself. If you prefer those older console games then that too is provided by assigning games to cartridges and swapping them over on the console provided in front of a retro CRT TV.NRA is still relatively new though and so is VR (at least decent useable VR) i.e. Oculus/ HTC Vive so the NRA team still have some features to add for the Arcade experience to finally reach its Climax and hit the G-Spot but for the most part it's all there already having added multiple style of cabinets, 4:3 screens, Vertical screens and Light Gun cabinets not to mention attract videos/ music oh and an old ghetto blaster to play music on.Sadly it's missing the little or big old lady sitting behind a counter offering change looking at you in disgust as if you should be in school.NRA is not without it's problems though, but that problem is not entirely the NRA teams fault it's the times we live in and the NRA team tries to achieve a balance of what can be achieved given pc resources available to the mass.One of the main requests the team gets is for a bigger arcade but i doubt that will happen for many years until more powerful computers are available to the masses. There is of course ways around this that the team is already looking into.NRA looks impressive even with lower end computers when using low resolution gfx/ art work and no attract videos but in order to achieve a truly amazing arcade look you need to use all the features available at high details, (High GFX settings, high resolution art work, high res attract video's and this can hit your wallet in the form of a high end gaming pc and we don't even have 4k per eye VR yet and that will really make NRA look out of this world.Oh did I mention it even has VHS tapes and a cinema room, well it does.If you liked the demo and wondering if you should pay out for the full version then the answer is yes.NRA has an amazing community of people willing to offer support for those who get stuck with the setup.For anyone who uses Emulators then NRA is easy to get to grips with and sadly those who are not can give up too easily without asking for assistance or looking in the right locations to make things easier.So my advice would be to persevere and you will not be disappointed with the end result.

Of course the choice is up to you and you could have a present day arcade if you wanted, Mario Kart DX Arcade anyone?So the TL:DR of it all is, this game is well worth buying if you like emulation and especially so if you own a VR headset though that isn't a requirement.

												This game is fun for me whether I use VR or not, and it was well worth the $18 to enjoy some 80s tunes inside a room scale VR arcade with emulators.  The visuals are very realistic with PBR and working arcade cabinets and even many non-rom minigames, including air hockey, bowling, dart throwing, mini basketball, test your punch boxing, whack-a-t-rex, and skeeball.  All that plus customizable controls, music, and visuals make this a fun toy but not quite a game you'll play for its own merits.  If not for the roms, which were a pain to set up (let alone find), I wouldn't have much reason to play this over all the other carnival style games out right now for Vive.  This game, however, offers some of the most realistic-looking minigames I've seen, meaning that they look like they came from an actual arcade or carnival somewhere.If you have some friends to play with, this game has some nice social features, including voice chat and multiplayer minigames. However, the game does not offer much in terms of character customization, and there's a clear divide between VR players and non-VR players.  VR players also have to make use of a separate gamepad for arcade cabinets because the Vive controller inputs (the touch pads specifically) tend to lag and sometimes not even register.  That said, playing old school Zelda games in a fake 80s arcade is kind of awesome.I recommend you try the demo first.  It's a good demo.  The demo is actually almost as good as the full version if you don't mind having only one level to choose from and don't care to have the theater room.  Keep in mind that both the demo and full version do not have working emulation from the start.  You have to get your own roms and emulators and set everything up, including the artwork and attract videos.

Hey, got a permit for that arcade?I received a Steam key from Digital Cybercherries for the purposes of review. This does not change my opinion whatsoever.This is a Non-VR Review, and is not reflective of the experience with playing the game in VR.New Retro Arcade: Neon isn’t the second coming of the world with a multiplayer experience unlike any other, but it’s a functioning glimpse into a future I can’t wait to live in.Pros:When the Emulation works, it runs wonderfully. The game doesn’t have any performance issues when another emulation is running inside the game.The Aesthetic harkens back to a classic 80s/90s age that even without VR is incredibly immersiveBeing able to play with VR and non-VR users with a multiplayer mode is legitimately amazing, with often little lag.A supportive developer that constantly updates the game, expanding it and really turning it’s bumpy launch into something else.Nitpicks:The Walking Speed for Non-VR users is incredibly slow, considering that those with VR could easily go around the map faster.Setting up the Arcade with your own ROMs, Videotapes, etc. could be explained better and is generally way too time-consuming. Online Guides are your best way to look for answers on doing this.Multiplayer seems severely underdeveloped, with the lack of Text Chat and the ability to interact with more of the machines/objects with other players.For it’s content and current state, it does seem that it’s price point is a bit too high.Cons:The game is still buggy with it’s emulation being a bit spotty at times, often producing weird results.The Current Manager for setting things up is comparatively less flexible and more convoluted to use versus what was present in the original Tech Demo.The ReviewNew Retro Arcade: Neon is an absolutely visceral experience. Complete with a Retro Flair and it’s engaging VR experience, it is something unlike any other. However, what does that mean for those without VR?I’m happy to say that it’s still a really good experience otherwise. There’s a good amount of customization to be had here with the Arcade Machines to the point where you can retrofit the machines to play and look exactly like your favorite arcade machines. However, it doesn’t seem to be well-explained just how to set up the Arcade with your own things, as a lot of the details seem to be not presented in any form inside the actual game. It will take and require a hefty amount of research, online guides, and possibly help from others to get your favorite Arcade Machines set up the way you want it to. However, even with knowledge on how to set things up, I found the Manager for it to be a mess and compared to the demo, lacking. It also does an incredibly poor job explaining the controls, with it’s confusing and occasionally buggy UI. While the Vive Motion Controllers make a lot of the objects more interactable, the keyboard/controller setup is confusing and sometimes a bit awkward.However, once you do figure out how things work and get all of your ROMs set up, it’s nothing short of amazing. As you play Arcade Machines and various minigames, you can hear the sounds of button mashing, loud music (that you can customize!), and more just playing in the background. While it’s emulation isn’t perfect, it’s clear that it isn’t really the main selling point of the Arcade, but rather it’s level of immersion and interactivity inside it. It’s whole idea of immersion just works, even when you’re not actually playing the game with VR.Now if that sounds amazing, then you should totally pick it up right now (because it’s pretty god dang rad) but it’s important to walk into it with different expectations. For one, the game’s multiplayer is incredibly underdeveloped, with the inability to interact with Emulated Games or non-online Movies with your friends, a lack of other methods of communication besides VoiceIP and only a handful of ways to interact with others. While it’s no doubt relatively decent and the online multiplayer works, it does not live up to just the full potential these kind of ideas have, and that’s still due to limiting technologies. That doesn’t diminish the fact that playing Bowling and Darts with others online is absolutely fun.It’s not without it’s issues, however. It’s rocky launch initially put me off of really playing it that much when it first came out, with it’s constant bugs, lack of Arcade Machines, and the emulation being spotty at best. However, since it’s launch, the developers have come and fixed the majority of the issues I’ve had with it when it came out, so I am thoroughly impressed with just how committed they are to this project. I’ve seen major patch notes fly out almost weekly and all of the devs communicate very well with the highly supportive community, which is probably one of the biggest highlights of the whole experience. It does seem like it would had fared better as a Early Access game but it does sound like we’ll be getting major additions in the future (and by future I mean very, very soon) that will really spice and elevate this thing to another level.But it’s price point may be the most troubling factor to it. As I’ve said, it does seem like it’s state is still in Early Access Territory, and it definitely is a steep price for those not playing it in VR or planning on playing it with friends. But those willing to take the plunge in early may find themselves surprised. It may take awhile to understand how to get everything set up, but New Retro Arcade: Neon is nothing like I’ve experienced before. It’s an interactive experience that while is still limited to the confines of technology today, is perhaps a glimpse in the future set in the neon-lights of our past.TL;DR - [New Retro Arcade: Neon successfully immerses the player into what is a glimpse of the future in the background of the past. If a few minor hiccups.] Final Recommendation: Cautiously Recommend for Non-VR users.For more reviews on all sorts of games, follow  Lots' o Giveaway's group curations and reviews  here!Be sure to check out the rest of my reviews for LOG on OpenCritic @ http://opencritic.com/outlet/380/lots-o-giveaways

												I'm going to recommend this game, but with a caveat: Be prepared for delayed gratification. The game is a pain to setup and the configuration tool is external and poorly designed. I'm a developer and, even for me, the amount of configuration was a bummer. You also may need to break out a graphics program to get your cabinet art sorted out - there is no online repository of any sort.But, once you're done with configuration, this program really is a gem. It's a nostalgia sandbox. I've loaded this thing down with my favorite music, movies and videos from my childhood and all the games that take me back. What I absolutely love is that the state is saved as you move away from a machine, meaning you can hop from machine to machine without worrying about restarting each time or working with a cumbersome save menu.I've messed around with emulation over the years, but it rarely held my interest for long as I start to get aggravated with moving through cartridge backups just for a moment's worth of pleasure. I didn't want to sit through an entire game - I wanted to go through a roster of games I used to enjoy, getting a jolt of memories and then move along to another. The work in-between is what killed it for me. This game saves me from that.So, as long as you're prepared for the setup, if this sounds interesting to you in any way whatsoever, pick it up. It's worth every penny, even in its current state. If this company were to shut down today, and no more updates were made, I'd still feel like I got my money's worth.UPDATE-------------I noticed other reviewers saying Anarchy Arcade was better, so I went and tried it out. From what I can see, Anarchy Arcade is meant as a 3D Arcade Style launcher, and definitely doesn't provide the nostalgia-fest New Retro Arcade Neon does. Yes, it allows you to launch any application, but that's it - it just launches it. NRA:N displays the game on the arcade screen, and you can zoom into it and choose what style effects to apply. Was the game on a CRT with scanlines? Was it an HD game? NRA:N lets you decide how you want to view it.Anarchy Arcade is definitely not accomplishing what NRA:N does - they're in different categories as far as I'm concerned, and, frankly, Anarchy Arcade looks like garbage. It allows you to customize your environment, but I can't see ever wanting to look at that for any length. The only thing I can say for Anarchy Arcade is that it does auto-populate cabinet art and that is a feature I think NRA:N could desparately use. I'd like to provide NRA:N with one image, say a logo, and have it extrapolate some interesting cabinet art that, while maybe not original, doesn't require any graphics editing.So, I still recommend New Retro Arcade Neon. I do not recommend Anarchy Arcade.

												This is an EA title and should be marked as such. I'm investing in the idea but it does need some love. Check the demo out, first. The Vive trackpad (D-Pad) controls are a little off so I have a Xbox One controller I use as a backup. VOIP needs to be implemented. Sharing movies works via YouTube streaming or by having the same movie file in the same directory on each participating multiplayer computer.Why get it now?You can:- Play emulated games solo.- Listen to cool music.- Watch movies with friends.- Play Air Hockey, bowling, basketball, skeet shooting, darts, a rails zombie shooter, a Flappy Bird knock off (by default), and a single stick multiplayer shooter.Why get it later?Hopefully, we can:- Have virtual couch co-op/game streaming.- Compete with high scores.I'd consider the game in Alpha because it's not feature complete. There are some known bugs and the multiplayer isn't finished. We'll get there.Update: It's been a few months and I've yet to see any progress regarding server hosting and game streaming. This was one of the majors draws to the game and whenever requested the dev team says it's simply too hard. However, between adopting something like Valve's Source hosting system wherein all of the host's files are downloaded by the client, and the success of streaming in Unity, sharing an arcade space is definitely possible.This game is an atmospheric, single player getaway for your oldschool needs. However, it's much easier to put these games up on your monitor/TV than go through the trouble of implementing them here. With RetroPie for the Rasberry Pi and other means of realizing a retro arcade experience this game simply isn't worthwhile (yet) without a more complete multiplayer experience. I go to Barcade to compete in high scores with friends/strangers. I can't do that here and therefore this game has been a nice, experimental escape, but doesn't have enough content to hold my attention. Arcades are about socializing and this game, right now, doesn't do a great job of that. I go to arcades to play arcade games; not just bowl or play arcade basketball.So here's to the developers realizing that somehow, at some point in the near future, before interest truly wanes.

												Recently got back into this title as it now supports Oculus Touch and a form of stick based locomotion. However, locomotion is where this title really falls apart. Let me explain:In order to move you need to be stood on top of circle marker, if you move outside of this marker you will no longer be able to move. I can understand the reason behind this but it basically means that most of your play session is spent fighting against this mechanic, searching for the circle if you physically moved outside of it. This is frustrating and could easily be resolved by having a button bound which moves said circle to the players current position. Sadly this option is not available. Secondly, stick based walking movement - I'm glad it was included but... It's a simple on or off, the position of your analog stick has no bearing on how fast or slow you move. i.e. you push your stick forward and you start to move, slow at first and quite quickly build up to a full on run no matter the position of you stick, hence you have no direct control over how fast you move through this games environment. Not only is this very bad practice in VR and a relic of past game design but it also prevents the end user from being able to slowly walk around their arcade in order to admire the arcade they have built. Essentially if you don't want to run everywhere like your on steroids or in a  90's first person shooter you end up having to use a start stop approach, press forward and then let go before you start moving to fast, press forward, let go and repeat. This makes for a very unpleasant experience and the game becomes a stuttery mess. I think the developers nailed the arcade environment, it is fantastic and looks amazing. However its impossible to fully enjoy the arcade with such poor movement controls. Resolving this issue should be priority for the development team but there seems to be no interest in doing so, I'm quite confident that we'll see more gimicks such as the playable guitar and drum machine rather than them focusing on resolving the underlying 'bad for VR' locomotion design.There are also other little niggles, like no audio being played when trying to watch a movie from one of the VHS tapes, the fact you are unable to sit on any of the chairs in the cinema (or anywhere else there is a chair or sofa) and if you could your view would be obstructed anyway, the position of the TV attached to the game console makes it impossible to sit down and enjoy and the fact that some of the emulation that works in the demo version of NRA does not work in the full paid for version. In honesty I think the devs need to take a long hard look at the foundations of this game and get things working correctly before spending time on more gimmicks which people may use once or twice and then never return to.If these issues were resolved I would recommend this title. In its current state I cannot.

To me nothing could beat that feeling of being a kid again and spending hours in an arcade.NRA:N has now become one of my go-to games for demoing the Vive right alongside theBlu, Old Friend, and the Lab.You cannot go wrong with this title.  The time I spent into getting all the ROMs, artwork, controls, etc. was definitely tedious, but was well worth it in the end.  Beautiful and polished graphics and lighting, bumping 80's like techno music, and hours of custom made content makes New Retro Arcade: Neon a must have for any 80's or 90's kid.

												UPDATE: I am updating my review because in the past week and a half I've seen the developers be very active with the community making a real effort to fix many of the problems with the initial release of this game.  At this point, many of my complaints have been addressed.  There are still issues I am waiting to be fixed, but I am confident that these will be fixed soon and at this point this has become the nostalgic dream I've really been waiting for so long!  Vive controls and positioning is still needing to be fixed, and we still really need to have attract screens with sound running on the arcades.  Shared video streams from friends arcades is still desperately desired.  Otherwise, if you want to feel like you are back in the 80's hanging out in your favorite arcade, this is the way to do it!  I wouldn't hesitate to purchase this game.  /END UPDATEI was really hoping I would enjoy the arcade machines in this, but the selection of roms that actually work without crashing the program seems very slim.  The default arcade that you get has only 3 functioning games, the rest are all dummy machines with a static image on them and no games.  The complete garbage of the throw in carnival games don't make up for the lack of arcade games.  Many of these add in "chuck-e-cheese" type games have already been done in other VR games, and have been done so much better.  --The Good--The visuals (after you figure out how to set the resolution in the settings) look pretty good.  The textures and the models of the arcade cabinets and other elements in the environment look very nice.  It is possible to get mame hooked up to some of these arcade machines and load your own roms.  It's a big guessing game as to where your configured arcade machines will be located, and then it's an excersize in frustration when you go in to try your new mame rom and get to experience a crash to desktop when all of your favorite roms just don't work.  --The Bad--Vive controllers for arcade game play absolutely sucks! input recognition on the touch pad is nowhere near good enough for fast arcade input.The carnival games:I decided to give some of the novelty games a go, since the vive controller input on those should be more natural for things like the light gun game, the punching bag, whack-a-mole etc.Punching bag game. what the heck? You don't even punch the thing! The only interaction I could get to work on the punching bag was to hover my vive controller inside the bag until it outlined in white, then pull the trigger. that seemed to "punch" it. that has got to be the stupidest thing I've ever seen.Whack-a-mole:First off, everytime i pick something up, it seems like it goes to the wrong hand, and even sometimes it picks up the completely wrong item. I tried to pick up the mallet on the right hand machine, with my right hand. It grabbed the mallet from the left hand machine (starting the left machine game) and put the mallet into my left hand. that's all sorts of screwed up. But ok, I'm in room scale, I'll just step over there to that machine. Most of my hits wouldn't register. Seemed like the very middle dinosaur just wouldn't register a hit no matter what. I gave up.Zombie Light Gun game:Then I went to play the zombie light gun game. This time the gun went into my correct hand, but what the heck is up with the reload function? I figured out that pressing on the touch pad button was reload (which is stupid, most light gun games I remember as a kid required you to simply shoot off screen to reload). But sometimes pressing the touch pad button actually shoots the gun. I couldn't ever really figure out where it wanted me to press to actually reload. so I got mad and quit.Skee-ball:it's like the skee balls have little jet engines in them and no matter how lightly you toss them, they go launching like they've been shot out of a canon. I know they are working on all of these bugs, but my goodness, this initial impression has made me wonder what in the world happened between the free version they made prior to this and the demo, and this release?  This feels like a rushed out half finished, mostly broken piece of junk to me. I hope this gets fixed soon.I'm still very anxious for this to work like the free version and the demo did. this has been my most anticipated game since the free version on the DK2.
